message.content: This question requires knowledge about the physical process of boiling. When water reaches its boiling point, it forms bubbles and produces visible signs of boiling. Option (A) is incorrect because the taste of water does not change when it boils. Option (B) is also incorrect because water does not have a distinct smell when it boils. Option (D) is clearly incorrect because cool water is not an indication that it is ready to cook noodles.

This question requires basic knowledge about the boiling point of water. Water boils when it reaches a temperature of 100 degrees Celsius (212 degrees Fahrenheit) at sea level. When water is boiling, it produces bubbles due to the rapid conversion of liquid water into vapor. Option (A) is incorrect because the taste of the water does not indicate if it is boiling or not. Option (B) is also incorrect because the smell of water does not change when it is boiling. Option (D) is incorrect because cool water is not an indicator that it is boiling, as boiling water is hot.
